author: potuz
jgm
content:
That's a simple JSON representation of the spec, and makes sense.  Only thing I would add is to make it an array.

Although note that most clients won't even need to import the JSON through a file, as there will be a REST API endpoint for it.

author: potuz
content: Yeah but whatever CLI command we do it needs to be fed something, the UX should be you run `ethdo` or `staking_cli` airgapped, it outputs *something* and then you run `teku withdraw something` on your staking machine. That something makes sense to me that it's a JSON as above. I'm happy if it's a different something, but whatever it is I'd like it to be defined in the next week so that we can implement the full endpoints right now.

author: jgm
content:
You can run `ethdo` on your online computer to send it, although frankly if you have generated the file already the same job could be done with `curl` and a bit of scripting.

The API is defined at https://github.com/ethereum/beacon-APIs/pull/248/

author: potuz
content: yeah that I want to avoid: it's fine if `ethdo` can send the messages, but clients need to implement this too and users shouldn't need to depend on one or another tooling to send their messages. And yes, a user with a JSON or ssz representation of the message should be able to do a curl, but I don't want to have to rely on users having `curl` in their systems (most Windows users don't) nor know how to POST, etc.

author: potuz
content: I can give you a branch that will work with 3024 implemented for testing next week, on your end it shouldn't make a difference, but on the CL side it's a consensus break from the current specs

author: jgm
content:
Fair enough, I think we should go with the array of signed messages then as our _de facto_ standard, unless anyone has any objections.

(For voluntary exits `ethdo` does add other information, but that's mainly because they can hang around on the filesystem for a while and expire.  Not sure that this is relevant for the credential change operation so keeping it simple seems like the best option.)
